values.description:
```
#!c++

<pre>$ ign msg --help
/usr/lib/ruby/2.3.0/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:55:in `require': cannot load such file -- /mnt/mervin/workspaces/delphyne/install/lib/ruby/ignition/cmdmsgs1 (LoadError)
        from /usr/lib/ruby/2.3.0/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:55:in `require'
        from /mnt/mervin/workspaces/delphyne/install/bin/ign:254:in `<main>'
```

The `.rb` conf file was not installed in a major version directory. With this pull request:


```
#!c++

caguero@bb20:~/workspace/ign-msgs/build$ ign msg
Print information about ignition messages.

  ign msg [options]

Options:

  -i [ --info ]         Get info about a message.
  -l [ --list ]         List all topics.
  -h [ --help ]              Print this help message.
  --force-version <VERSION>  Use a specific library version.
  --versions                 Show the available versions.
```

values.description: It might be the case that we're requesting a long step and I'd like to update the world statistics to capture this case (e.g.: for disabling the step button on the clients and prevent another step while the first is still ongoing).
values.title: Add stepping field to world_stats message

values.description:
Added inline namespaces, and disabled Generator from being installed.

Inline namespaces for the messages will come later (I'm aware that protobuf recommends not distributing the generated messages).

Also removed Generator from installation. In order to remove doxygen documentation I renamed the class to Private.
values.title: Inline namespace

summary.raw:
Added inline namespaces, and disabled Generator from being installed.

Inline namespaces for the messages will come later (I'm aware that protobuf recommends not distributing the generated messages).

Also removed Generator from installation. In order to remove doxygen documentation I renamed the class to Private.
summary.html:
Added inline namespaces, and disabled Generator from being installed.

Inline namespaces for the messages will come later (I'm aware that protobuf recommends not distributing the generated messages).

Also removed Generator from installation. In order to remove doxygen documentation I renamed the class to Private.

values.description:
This pull request extends the `Factory` class to support the creation of a Protobuf message at runtime based on its message descriptor. The descriptor (`.desc`) can be triggered with the option `--descriptor_set_out=FILE`. We also assume that descriptors are generated with the option `include_imports` that include all dependencies of the input file, so the descriptor is self-contained.

How to test this PR?

* Compile the Ignition Transport examples and run `./publisher_custom_msg`
* Open a new terminal and point `IGN_DESCRIPTOR_DIR` to `<YOUR_IGN_MSG_REPO>/test/desc`. Here's the descriptor `stringmsg.desc` for the message published by `publisher_custom_msg`.
* Run `ign topic -t /foo -e` and you should be able to introspect the custom message.

Note: I needed some functionality of `Ignition::common::Filesystem` for iterating over a list of files in a given directory. I copied a subset of that class from Ignition Common here. We can remove this code when Ignition Common components are ready. I'm also open to suggestions if you think there's a better way of doing it.

Thanks also to @peter_mitrano , who started working on this feature a while ago.
values.title: Extend Factory class

summary.raw:
This pull request extends the `Factory` class to support the creation of a Protobuf message at runtime based on its message descriptor. The descriptor (`.desc`) can be triggered with the option `--descriptor_set_out=FILE`. We also assume that descriptors are generated with the option `include_imports` that include all dependencies of the input file, so the descriptor is self-contained.

How to test this PR?

* Compile the Ignition Transport examples and run `./publisher_custom_msg`
* Open a new terminal and point `IGN_DESCRIPTOR_DIR` to `<YOUR_IGN_MSG_REPO>/test/desc`. Here's the descriptor `stringmsg.desc` for the message published by `publisher_custom_msg`.
* Run `ign topic -t /foo -e` and you should be able to introspect the custom message.

Note: I needed some functionality of `Ignition::common::Filesystem` for iterating over a list of files in a given directory. I copied a subset of that class from Ignition Common here. We can remove this code when Ignition Common components are ready. I'm also open to suggestions if you think there's a better way of doing it.

Thanks also to @peter_mitrano , who started working on this feature a while ago.
summary.html:
This pull request extends the Factory class to support the creation of a Protobuf message at runtime based on its message descriptor. The descriptor (.desc) can be triggered with the option --descriptor_set_out=FILE. We also assume that descriptors are generated with the option include_imports that include all dependencies of the input file, so the descriptor is self-contained.

How to test this PR?

  • Compile the Ignition Transport examples and run ./publisher_custom_msg
  • Open a new terminal and point IGN_DESCRIPTOR_DIR to <YOUR_IGN_MSG_REPO>/test/desc. Here's the descriptor stringmsg.desc for the message published by publisher_custom_msg.
  • Run ign topic -t /foo -e and you should be able to introspect the custom message.

Note: I needed some functionality of Ignition::common::Filesystem for iterating over a list of files in a given directory. I copied a subset of that class from Ignition Common here. We can remove this code when Ignition Common components are ready. I'm also open to suggestions if you think there's a better way of doing it.

Thanks also to @peter_mitrano , who started working on this feature a while ago.

values.description:
The `UNIT_ign_TEST` has been failing on homebrew:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64&build=7)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64/7/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64/7/testReport/

I've melded changes from ign-transport to fix UNIT_ign_TEST and also switched to use `libignition-tools-dev` in the pipeline.

There's a lot of code needed to support this test spread between `conf/CMakeLists.txt`, `src/cmd/CMakeLists.txt`, `test/test_config.h.in`, `tools/ign_TEST.cc` in addition to the yaml and ruby files that actually get installed. It would be nice to have some helpers in ign-cmake to clean this up a bit.
values.title: Fix UNIT_ign_TEST on homebrew

summary.raw:
The `UNIT_ign_TEST` has been failing on homebrew:

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64&build=7)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64/7/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64/7/testReport/

I've melded changes from ign-transport to fix UNIT_ign_TEST and also switched to use `libignition-tools-dev` in the pipeline.

There's a lot of code needed to support this test spread between `conf/CMakeLists.txt`, `src/cmd/CMakeLists.txt`, `test/test_config.h.in`, `tools/ign_TEST.cc` in addition to the yaml and ruby files that actually get installed. It would be nice to have some helpers in ign-cmake to clean this up a bit.
summary.html:
The UNIT_ign_TEST has been failing on homebrew:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_msgs-ci-ign-msgs1-homebrew-amd64/7/testReport/

I've melded changes from ign-transport to fix UNIT_ign_TEST and also switched to use libignition-tools-dev in the pipeline.

There's a lot of code needed to support this test spread between conf/CMakeLists.txt, src/cmd/CMakeLists.txt, test/test_config.h.in, tools/ign_TEST.cc in addition to the yaml and ruby files that actually get installed. It would be nice to have some helpers in ign-cmake to clean this up a bit.

values.description: If the ignition-msgs library is not installed in the system the ign test will [fail to load it](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ign-msgs2-debbuilder/9/console). Add the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`to the ctest system will make it to success.
values.title: ign test needs LIBRARY_PATH for libignition-msgs2.so

summary.raw: If the ignition-msgs library is not installed in the system the ign test will [fail to load it](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ign-msgs2-debbuilder/9/console). Add the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`to the ctest system will make it to success.
summary.html: If the ignition-msgs library is not installed in the system the ign test will fail to load it. Add the LD_LIBRARY_PATHto the ctest system will make it to success.

values.description:
Upgrade to proto3 and fix compiler issues.

Converting to proto3 involved:

1. changing the `syntax` from `proto2` to `proto3`
2. Remove `optional` and `required`
3. All `enums` must start from 0.
4. Remove explicit default values.
5. Suppress some new compiler warnings in `Generator.cc`

‌
values.title: Proto3

summary.raw:
Upgrade to proto3 and fix compiler issues.

Converting to proto3 involved:

1. changing the `syntax` from `proto2` to `proto3`
2. Remove `optional` and `required`
3. All `enums` must start from 0.
4. Remove explicit default values.
5. Suppress some new compiler warnings in `Generator.cc`

‌
summary.html:
Upgrade to proto3 and fix compiler issues.

Converting to proto3 involved:

  1. changing the syntax from proto2 to proto3
  2. Remove optional and required
  3. All enums must start from 0.
  4. Remove explicit default values.
  5. Suppress some new compiler warnings in Generator.cc

‌

values.description: This uses the addition of protobuf components in [this ign-cmake PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/81/) to specify that ign-msgs2 needs all protobuf components. This should provide cleaner build errors for users who only have some of the protobuf components installed.
values.title: Specify that we need all components of Protobuf

summary.raw: This uses the addition of protobuf components in [this ign-cmake PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/81/) to specify that ign-msgs2 needs all protobuf components. This should provide cleaner build errors for users who only have some of the protobuf components installed.
summary.html: This uses the addition of protobuf components in this ign-cmake PR to specify that ign-msgs2 needs all protobuf components. This should provide cleaner build errors for users who only have some of the protobuf components installed.

values.description:
* Remove `edit_name` (see #25)
* `clone_model_name` -> `clone_name` to be more general
* Add `oneof` since only one method is supported at a time
* Add `Model`
* Add `name` to allow overriding the name on SDF (as a reference, `gazebo_ros_pkgs` currently [accepts](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/ros2/gazebo_msgs/srv/SpawnEntity.srv) that)

`gazebo_ros_pkgs` also has a `reference_frame` option for the pose which I didn't add here because the implementation can be a bit involved (frame has to exist, calculate the relative pose...), so I feel that it's the kind of thing that the user of the service should be handling instead, but I can be convinced otherwise (and I can implement it for ign-gazebo in that case).
values.title: [A-6] Refactor factory

summary.raw:
* Remove `edit_name` (see #25)
* `clone_model_name` -> `clone_name` to be more general
* Add `oneof` since only one method is supported at a time
* Add `Model`
* Add `name` to allow overriding the name on SDF (as a reference, `gazebo_ros_pkgs` currently [accepts](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/ros2/gazebo_msgs/srv/SpawnEntity.srv) that)

`gazebo_ros_pkgs` also has a `reference_frame` option for the pose which I didn't add here because the implementation can be a bit involved (frame has to exist, calculate the relative pose...), so I feel that it's the kind of thing that the user of the service should be handling instead, but I can be convinced otherwise (and I can implement it for ign-gazebo in that case).
summary.html:
• Remove edit_name (see #25)
  • clone_model_name -> clone_name to be more general
  • Add oneof since only one method is supported at a time
  • Add Model
  • Add name to allow overriding the name on SDF (as a reference, gazebo_ros_pkgs currently accepts that)

gazebo_ros_pkgs also has a reference_frame option for the pose which I didn't add here because the implementation can be a bit involved (frame has to exist, calculate the relative pose...), so I feel that it's the kind of thing that the user of the service should be handling instead, but I can be convinced otherwise (and I can implement it for ign-gazebo in that case).

values.description:
## Motivation

On Gazebo Classic™,  entities had integer unique IDs, and also string names, so several messages accept both types of identification. See [pose.proto](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/954c692189352b70b1946b4b14d0293416d14b78/proto/ignition/msgs/pose.proto?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#pose.proto-36) for example.

While `id`s are efficient and unique, `name`s are user-friendly, so it's good to have both options.

### Name uniqueness

We currently have several issues on Gazebo Classic due to names (and scoped names) not being unique. The `entity_info` service [can't tell links from joints](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1451/modellistwidget-doesnt-display-joint-info), the `entity_delete` service can't tell models from lights...

One solution for this could involve enforcing unique scoped names. However, we would also like to let users rename entities after they've been created. This poses a problem in the ECS, because the name component will need to be writable, but we can't count on the systems to enforce uniqueness.

So my suggestion is to use the following assumptions:

1. IDs are unique across all types.
1. Names are not unique across types.
1. Names may be unique within a type, but we will not enforce this.

## Summary

I propose the following message, which has `id`, `name` and `type`. The way I expect it to be used is:

~~~
if id not null
  use id
else if name not null and type not null
  use name + type
else
  error
end
~~~

> I considered using `oneof`, but certain use cases may want to use the message to notify all fields together, so they can all be set.

When using `name` + `type`, the user should be aware that if many entities have the same combination, only one will be affected.

If this is accepted, `kNullEntity` should be changed to zero on `ign-gazebo`.

## Immediate future

If this is accepted, its first user will be the new entity delete service, and in the future we should use it for any other commands that refer to specific entities.
values.title: [A-6] Message to uniquely identify an entity

On Gazebo Classic™,  entities had integer unique IDs, and also string names, so several messages accept both types of identification. See [pose.proto](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/954c692189352b70b1946b4b14d0293416d14b78/proto/ignition/msgs/pose.proto?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#pose.proto-36) for example.

We currently have several issues on Gazebo Classic due to names (and scoped names) not being unique. One solution for this could involve enforcing unique scoped names. However, we would also like to let users rename entities after they've been created. This poses a problem in the ECS, because the name component will need to be writable, but we can't count on the systems to enforce uniqueness.

So my suggestion is to use the following assumptions:

1. Names are not unique across types.
1. Names may be unique within a type, but we will not enforce this.

summary.html:
Motivation

On Gazebo Classic™, entities had integer unique IDs, and also string names, so several messages accept both types of identification. See pose.proto for example.

While ids are efficient and unique, names are user-friendly, so it's good to have both options.

Name uniqueness

We currently have several issues on Gazebo Classic due to names (and scoped names) not being unique. The entity_info service can't tell links from joints, the entity_delete service can't tell models from lights...

One solution for this could involve enforcing unique scoped names. However, we would also like to let users rename entities after they've been created. This poses a problem in the ECS, because the name component will need to be writable, but we can't count on the systems to enforce uniqueness.

So my suggestion is to use the following assumptions:

  1. IDs are unique across all types.
  2. Names are not unique across types.
  3. Names may be unique within a type, but we will not enforce this.

Summary

I propose the following message, which has id, name and type. The way I expect it to be used is:

if id not null
  use id
else if name not null and type not null
  use name + type
else
  error
end

I considered using oneof, but certain use cases may want to use the message to notify all fields together, so they can all be set.

When using name + type, the user should be aware that if many entities have the same combination, only one will be affected.

If this is accepted, kNullEntity should be changed to zero on ign-gazebo.

Immediate future

If this is accepted, its first user will be the new entity delete service, and in the future we should use it for any other commands that refer to specific entities.
